Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns the theoretical exploration of the properties of strongly interacting matter at ultra-high densities (10 to 20 times denser than atomic nuclei) and temperatures (several hundred billion degrees). It is generally accepted by the scientific community that the universe was filled with super-dense matter shortly after the Big Bang. Super-dense matter continues to be created in the final stages of catastrophic stellar events, such as core-collapse supernovae and gamma-ray bursts, and it may be present deep inside the cores of collapsed stars, known as neutron stars. Neutron stars are typically about 20 kilometers across and spin rapidly, often making many hundred of rotations per second. A thimble full of neutron star matter would have a mass of one billion tons! At such extraordinary conditions atoms themselves collapse, and atomic nuclei are squeezed so tightly together that new fundamental particles are generated and novel states of matter are created. This makes neutron stars, and the catastrophic stellar events creating them, into excellent astrophysical laboratories for a wide range of physical studies, which are addressed in this project. Theoretical predictions concerning the equation of state of matter under these extreme conditions can be used to compare the results of simulations with observational data accumulating rapidly from both orbiting and ground based observatories spanning the radiation spectrum from X-rays to radio wavelengths.

This project focuses on the role of quark deconfinement for (proto) neutron stars and core-collapse supernova events, using a state-of-the-art (non-local 3-flavor Polyakov-Nambu-Jona-Lasinio, n3PNJL) model for the description of quark matter. The n3PNJL model accounts for the dynamical breaking of chiral symmetry and mimics quark confinement via the Polyakov loop potential. In recent years, the Nambu-Jona-Lasinio model has become the workhorse for various studies in theoretical nuclear physics, as it provides a very versatile and numerically treatable approach to the theory of the strong interaction (quantum chromodynamics, QCD). This research will consists of five intertwined activities concerning (1) the equation of state of cold quark-hybrid matter; (2) color superconductivity treated in the framework of the n3PNJL model; (3) quark deconfinement in (proto) neutron stars; (4) the properties of a quark-hadron Coulomb lattice that may exist in the cores of neutron stars; and (5) the role of quark deconfinement for core-collapse supernovae. The best available data from heavy ion collisions and neutron star observations will be used to impose the strongest possible constraints on the equation of state that will be developed in the framework of this research project. The equations of state will be made available to the wider nuclear and astrophysics community to explore the birth, structure and evolution of (proto) neutron stars and the events which create them.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Introduction

The focal point of this research projectconcerns our understanding of the phases of superhot and/or superdense matter where the physical conditions are so extreme that atoms themselves collapse and atomic nuclei are squeezed so tightly together that new particles and novel states of matter are created. One of the most spectacular possibilities is the formation of a plasma of quarks and gluons, referred to as quark matter. The universe was filled with such matter for a fleeting moment after the Big Bang. Quark matter, along with other novel states of matter, could also form a permanent component of the matter deep in the cores of so-called “neutron” stars, which are detected in ever increasing number, with radio telescopes and X-ray satellites. To keep up with the analysis and interpretation of the huge amount of data provided by these detections, detailed theoretical studies of the properties of neutron stars and the matter inside of them need to be carried out which utilize the latest advances in theoretical nuclear and  particle physics.

Key Accomplishments

The 3-quark-flavor Polyakov-Nambu-Jona-Lasinio (NJL) model has been used to compute the properties of quark matter. This model allows for a state-of-the-art treatment of quark matter. Numerical codes solving the field equations of the local as well as non-local extension of NJLmodel have been written from scratch.

A state-of-the-art collection of nuclear equations of state has been computed which is compatible with all currently available constraints from nuclear physics (heavy-ion collision data, asymmetry energy, slope parameter, nuclear incompressibility) and astrophysics (neutron star masses, radii, spin periods, redshifts, temperatures; gravitational mass-baryon mass relationship of collapsing carbon-oxygen).

A fully general relativistic cooling code has been developed from scratch which has been used to study the thermal evolution of rotating neutron stars (pulsars). During spin-down, such stars experience substantial increases in density, which, as has been demonstrated in our work, can trigger the creation of quark matter in the cores of rotating neutron stars. This will lead to changes in the thermal evolution of such objects, which could potentially be observed with X-ray telescopes.  

Our stellar rotation code has been modified so that it can also be used to study the properties of rotating white dwarfs (so-called white dwarf pulsars). This is motivated by NASA and JAXA observations which have challenged the conventional understanding of whitedwarfs. One such unusual white dwarf pulsar in ARSco. We have modeled the bulk properties of rapidly rotating white dwarfs, studied the evolution of their magnetic fields, and explored the role of pycno-nuclear and electron capture reactions driven by stellar spin-down. 

The properties of neutron stars are generally computed for equations of state that describe perfectly isotropic (nuclear) matter. This may not be correct, however, if color superconducting quark matter should be present in the cores of neutron stars. As shown by E. Ferrer et al. (PRC 82 (2010 6), this novel phase of matter can lead to strongly non-isotropic pressure distributions in the cores of neutron stars, which would render the shapes of neutron stars non-spherical. We have studied the properties and the deformity of such objects. For this purpose, the stellar structure equations of non-spherical compact stellar objects have been derived from Einstein's theory of general relativity. This had not been done before. We have found that even small non-isotropies can lead to pronounced changes in mass and radius, which is very important for the interpretation of massive compact objects as either neutron stars or solar-mass black holes.

We have determined the size and structure of a crystalline quark-hadron Coulomb lattice, which has been theorized to exist in the cores of neutron stars. Electrons, which exist abundantly in the cores of neutron stars, will then scatter off quark-lattice sites leading to Bremsstrahlung and the emission of neutrino-antineutrino pairs. The neutrino emission rates (i.e., energy loss) caused by Bremsstrahlung have been computed. They have been found to be of importance for the thermal evolution of older neutron stars if the direct URCA process is not operating.

If quark matter should exist in the cores of neutron stars, the energetically favorable state of such matter would be a color superconductor, where pairs of quarks bind together to form Cooper pairs. In this study, we have analyzed the stability and maximum mass of neutron stars with color superconducting quark matter cores.  We have found that a sharp hadron-quark tends to make the star unstable. Pure quark matter cores are found for some case studies, but these core all turn out to be very small.  

Six undergraduate and 5 graduate physics students have been trained areas of physics which are richly interdisciplinary. This enriches their educational experience beyond what they have learned in the classroom, giving them a strong competitive edge when applying to grad school or navigating their professional careers outside of academia.
